standard_metadata.standard_description: Multiply a whole number of up to four digits by a one-digit whole number, and multiply two two-digit numbers, using strategies based on place value and the properties of operations. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Multiply 3- and 4-digits by 1-digit with area models

question.content: The following area model shows $2\times459$ broken into parts.    *The image is not drawn to scale.*    **Find the area of each rectangle.**  $A=$   $B=$   $C=$    **Find the total area.**  $2\times459=$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 3 unequal parts, all with a width of 2 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled A, B, and C, and the lengths, also from left to right, are 400, 50, and 9.

hints.content: The area of the whole rectangle is $2 \times 459$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 3 unequal parts, all with a width of 2 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled A, B, and C. A curved bracket above all 3 parts is labeled 459.

hints.content: To find the area of each part, we multiply its length by its width.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align}\greenE{A}&=\greenE{400\times2} \\\\ &=\greenE{800} \\\\ \purpleD{B}&=\purpleD{50\times2}\\\\ &=\purpleD{100} \\\\ \redD{C}&=\redD{9\times2}\\\\ &=\redD{18} \end{align}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 3 unequal parts, all with a width of 2 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled 400 times 2, 50 times 2, and 9 times 2, and the lengths, also from left to right, are 400, 50, and 9.

hints.content: Now we add the areas to find the total.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\greenE{800}+\purpleD{100} +\redD{18}=918$  So $2 \times 459 = 918$.

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 3 unequal parts, all with a width of 2 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled 800, 100, and 18, and the lengths, also from left to right, are 400, 50, and 9.

hints.content: These are the areas:  $\begin{align} &A=800\\\\ &B=100\\\\ &C=18\\\\ &2 \times 459=918 \end{align}$

question.content: The following area model shows $574\times8$ broken into parts.    *The image is not drawn to scale.*    **Find the area of each rectangle.**  $A=$    $B=$    $C=$    **Find the total area.**  $574\times8=$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 3 unequal parts, all with a width of 8 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled A, B, and C, and the lengths, also from left to right, are 500, 70, and 4.

hints.content: The area of the whole rectangle is $8 \times 574$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 3 unequal parts, all with a width of 8 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled A, B, and C. A curved bracket above all 3 parts is labeled 574.

hints.content: To find the area of each part, we multiply its length by its width.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align}\greenE{A}&=\greenE{500\times8} \\\\ &=\greenE{4{,}000} \\\\ \purpleD{B}&=\purpleD{70\times8}\\\\ &=\purpleD{560} \\\\ \redD{C}&=\redD{4\times8}\\\\ &=\redD{32} \end{align}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 3 unequal parts, all with a width of 8 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled 500 times 8, 70 times 8, and 4 times 8, and the lengths, also from left to right, are 500, 70, and 4.

hints.content: Now we add the areas to find the total.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\greenE{4{,}000}+\purpleD{560} +\redD{32}=4{,}592$  So $8 \times 574 = 4{,}592$.

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 3 unequal parts, all with a width of 8 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled 4000, 560, and 32, and the lengths, also from left to right, are 500, 70, and 4.

hints.content: These are the areas:  $\begin{align} &A=4{,}000\\\\ &B=560\\\\ &C=32\\\\ &8 \times 574=4{,}592 \end{align}$

question.content: The following area model shows $5\times119$ broken into parts.    *The image is not drawn to scale.*    **Find the area of each rectangle.**  $A=$    $B=$    $C=$    **Find the total area.**  $5\times119=$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 3 unequal parts, all with a width of 5 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled A, B, and C. A curved bracket above all 3 parts is labeled 119.

hints.content: To find the area of each part, we multiply its length by its width.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align}\greenE{A}&=\greenE{100\times5} \\\\ &=\greenE{500} \\\\ \purpleD{B}&=\purpleD{10\times5}\\\\ &=\purpleD{50} \\\\ \redD{C}&=\redD{9\times5}\\\\ &=\redD{32} \end{align}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 3 unequal parts, all with a width of 5 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled 100 times 5, 10 times 5, and 9 times 5, and the lengths, also from left to right, are 100, 10, and 9.

hints.content: Now we add the areas to find the total.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\greenE{500}+\purpleD{50} +\redD{45}=595$  So $5 \times 119 = 595$.

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 3 unequal parts, all with a width of 5 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled 500, 50, and 45, and the lengths, also from left to right, are 100, 10, and 9.

hints.content: These are the areas:  $\begin{align} &A=500\\\\ &B=50\\\\ &C=45\\\\ &5 \times 119=595 \end{align}$

question.content: The following area model shows $483\times6$ broken into parts.    *The image is not drawn to scale.*    **Find the area of each rectangle.**  $A=$    $B=$    $C=$    **Find the total area.**  $483\times6=$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 3 unequal parts, all with a width of 6 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled A, B, and C, and the lengths, also from left to right, are 400, 80, and 3.

hints.content: The area of the whole rectangle is $483 \times 6$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 3 unequal parts, all with a width of 6 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled A, B, and C. A curved bracket above all 3 parts is labeled 483.

hints.content: To find the area of each part, we multiply its length by its width.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align}\greenE{A}&=\greenE{400\times6} \\\\ &=\greenE{2{,}400} \\\\ \purpleD{B}&=\purpleD{80\times6}\\\\ &=\purpleD{480} \\\\ \redD{C}&=\redD{3\times6}\\\\ &=\redD{18} \end{align}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 3 unequal parts, all with a width of 6 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled 400 times 6, 80 times 6, and 3 times 6, and the lengths, also from left to right, are 400, 80, and 3.

hints.content: Now we add the areas to find the total.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\greenE{2{,}400}+\purpleD{480} +\redD{18}=2{,}898$  So $483\times 6 = 2{,}898$.

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 3 unequal parts, all with a width of 6 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled 2400, 480, and 18, and the lengths, also from left to right, are 400, 80, and 3.

hints.content: These are the areas:  $\begin{align} &A=2{,}400\\\\ &B=480\\\\ &C=18\\\\ &483\times 6=2{,}898 \end{align}$

question.content: The following area model shows $6\times781$ broken into parts.    *The image is not drawn to scale.*    **Find the area of each rectangle.**  $A=$    $B=$    $C=$    **Find the total area.**  $6\times781=$

hints.content: To find the area of each part, we multiply its length by its width.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align}\greenE{A}&=\greenE{700\times6} \\\\ &=\greenE{4{,}200} \\\\ \purpleD{B}&=\purpleD{80\times6}\\\\ &=\purpleD{480} \\\\ \redD{C}&=\redD{1\times6}\\\\ &=\redD{6} \end{align}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 3 unequal parts, all with a width of 6 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled 700 times 6, 80 times 6, and 1 times 6, and the lengths, also from left to right, are 700, 80, and 1.

hints.content: Now we add the areas to find the total.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\greenE{4{,}200}+\purpleD{480} +\redD{6}=4{,}686$  So $6\times 781 = 4{,}686$.

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 3 unequal parts, all with a width of 6 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled 4200, 480, and 6, and the lengths, also from left to right, are 700, 80, and 1.

hints.content: These are the areas:  $\begin{align} &A=4{,}200\\\\ &B=480\\\\ &C=6\\\\ &6\times 781=4{,}686 \end{align}$

question.content: The following area model shows $7\times229$ broken into parts.    *The image is not drawn to scale.*    **Find the area of each rectangle.**  $A=$    $B=$    $C=$    **Find the total area.**  $7\times229=$

hints.content: The area of the whole rectangle is $7 \times 229$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 3 unequal parts, all with a width of 7 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled A, B, and C. A curved bracket above all 3 parts is labeled 229.

hints.content: To find the area of each part, we multiply its length by its width.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align}\greenE{A}&=\greenE{200\times7} \\\\ &=\greenE{1{,}400} \\\\ \purpleD{B}&=\purpleD{20\times7}\\\\ &=\purpleD{140} \\\\ \redD{C}&=\redD{9\times7}\\\\ &=\redD{63} \end{align}$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 3 unequal parts, all with a width of 7 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled 200 times 7, 20 times 7, and 9 times 7, and the lengths, also from left to right, are 200, 20, and 9.

hints.content: Now we add the areas to find the total.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\greenE{1{,}400}+\purpleD{140} +\redD{63}=1{,}603$  So $7\times 229 = 1{,}603$.

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 3 unequal parts, all with a width of 7 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled 1400, 140, and 63, and the lengths, also from left to right, are 200, 20, and 9.

hints.content: These are the areas:  $\begin{align} &A=1{,}400\\\\ &B=140\\\\ &C=63\\\\ &7\times 229=1{,}603 \end{align}$

question.content: The following area model shows $3{,}538\times5$ broken into parts.    *The image is not drawn to scale.*    **Find the area of each rectangle.**  $A=$    $B=$    $C=$   $D=$    **Find the total area.**  $3{,}538\times5=$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 4 unequal parts, all with a width of 5 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled A, B, C, and D, and the lengths, also from left to right, are 3000, 500, 30, and 8.

hints.content: The area of the whole rectangle is $3{,}538\times5$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 4 unequal parts, all with a width of 5 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled A, B, C, and D. A curved bracket above all 4 parts is labeled 3538.

hints.content: To find the area of each part, we multiply its length by its width.  $\begin{align}\greenE{A}&=\greenE{3{,}000\times5} \\\\ &=\greenE{15{,}000} \\\\ \purpleD{B}&=\purpleD{500\times5}\\\\ &=\purpleD{2{,}500} \\\\ \redD{C}&=\redD{30\times5}\\\\ &=\redD{150} \\\\ \blueD{D}&=\blueD{8\times5}\\\\ &=\blueD{40} \end{align}$
Now we add the areas to find the total.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\greenE{15{,}000}+\purpleD{2{,}500} +\redD{150}+\blueD{40}=17{,}690$  So $3{,}538 \times 5 = 17{,}690$.

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 4 unequal parts, all with a width of 5 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled 15000, 2500, 150, and 40, and the lengths, also from left to right, are 3000, 500, 30, and 8.

question.content: The following area model shows $4{,}663\times2$ broken into parts.    *The image is not drawn to scale.*    **Find the area of each rectangle.**  $A=$    $B=$    $C=$   $D=$    **Find the total area.**  $4{,}663\times2=$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 4 unequal parts, all with a width of 2 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled A, B, C, and D, and the lengths, also from left to right, are 4000, 600, 60, and 3.

hints.content: The area of the whole rectangle is $4{,}663\times2$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 4 unequal parts, all with a width of 2 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled A, B, C, and D. A curved bracket above all 4 parts is labeled 4663.

hints.content: To find the area of each part, we multiply its length by its width.  $\begin{align}\greenE{A}&=\greenE{4{,}000\times2} \\\\ &=\greenE{8{,}000} \\\\ \purpleD{B}&=\purpleD{600\times2}\\\\ &=\purpleD{1{,}200} \\\\ \redD{C}&=\redD{60\times2}\\\\ &=\redD{120} \\\\ \blueD{D}&=\blueD{3\times2}\\\\ &=\blueD{6} \end{align}$
Now we add the areas to find the total.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\greenE{8{,}000}+\purpleD{1{,}200} +\redD{120}+\blueD{6}=9{,}326$  So $4{,}663 \times 2 = 9{,}326$.

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 4 unequal parts, all with a width of 2 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled 8000, 1200, 120, and 6, and the lengths, also from left to right, are 4000, 600, 60, and 3.

question.content: The following area model shows $6\times5{,}432$ broken into parts.    *The image is not drawn to scale.*    **Find the area of each rectangle.**  $A=$    $B=$    $C=$   $D=$    **Find the total area.**  $6\times5{,}432=$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 4 unequal parts, all with a width of 6 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled A, B, C, and D, and the lengths, also from left to right, are 5000, 400, 30, and 2.

hints.content: The area of the whole rectangle is $6\times5{,}432$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 4 unequal parts, all with a width of 6 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled A, B, C, and D. A curved bracket above all 4 parts is labeled 5432.

hints.content: To find the area of each part, we multiply its length by its width.  $\begin{align}\greenE{A}&=\greenE{5{,}000\times6} \\\\ &=\greenE{30{,}000} \\\\ \purpleD{B}&=\purpleD{400\times6}\\\\ &=\purpleD{2{,}400} \\\\ \redD{C}&=\redD{30\times6}\\\\ &=\redD{180} \\\\ \blueD{D}&=\blueD{2\times6}\\\\ &=\blueD{12} \end{align}$
Now we add the areas to find the total.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\greenE{30{,}000}+\purpleD{2{,}400} +\redD{180}+\blueD{12}=32{,}592$  So $6 \times 5{,}432 = 32{,}592$.

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 4 unequal parts, all with a width of 6 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled 30000, 2400, 180, and 12, and the lengths, also from left to right, are 5000, 400, 30, and 2.

question.content: The following area model shows $3\times6{,}329$ broken into parts.    *The image is not drawn to scale.*    **Find the area of each rectangle.**  $A=$    $B=$    $C=$   $D=$    **Find the total area.**  $3\times6{,}329=$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 4 unequal parts, all with a width of 3 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled A, B, C, and D, and the lengths, also from left to right, are 6000, 300, 20, and 9.

hints.content: The area of the whole rectangle is $3\times6{,}329$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 4 unequal parts, all with a width of 3 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled A, B, C, and D. A curved bracket above all 4 parts is labeled 6329.

hints.content: To find the area of each part, we multiply its length by its width.  $\begin{align}\greenE{A}&=\greenE{6{,}000\times3} \\\\ &=\greenE{18{,}000} \\\\ \purpleD{B}&=\purpleD{300\times3}\\\\ &=\purpleD{900} \\\\ \redD{C}&=\redD{20\times3}\\\\ &=\redD{60} \\\\ \blueD{D}&=\blueD{9\times3}\\\\ &=\blueD{27} \end{align}$
Now we add the areas to find the total.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\greenE{18{,}000}+\purpleD{900} +\redD{60}+\blueD{27}=18{,}987$  So $3 \times 6{,}329 = 18{,}987$.

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 4 unequal parts, all with a width of 3 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled 18000, 900, 60, and 27, and the lengths, also from left to right, are 6000, 300, 20, and 9.

question.content: The following area model shows $9{,}721\times3$ broken into parts.    *The image is not drawn to scale.*    **Find the area of each rectangle.**  $A=$    $B=$    $C=$   $D=$    **Find the total area.**  $9{,}721\times3=$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 4 unequal parts, all with a width of 3 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled A, B, C, and D, and the lengths, also from left to right, are 9000, 700, 20, and 1.

hints.content: The area of the whole rectangle is $9{,}721\times3$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 4 unequal parts, all with a width of 3 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled A, B, C, and D. A curved bracket above all 4 parts is labeled 9721.

hints.content: To find the area of each part, we multiply its length by its width.  $\begin{align}\greenE{A}&=\greenE{9{,}000\times3} \\\\ &=\greenE{27{,}000} \\\\ \purpleD{B}&=\purpleD{700\times3}\\\\ &=\purpleD{2{,}100} \\\\ \redD{C}&=\redD{20\times3}\\\\ &=\redD{60} \\\\ \blueD{D}&=\blueD{1\times3}\\\\ &=\blueD{3} \end{align}$
Now we add the areas to find the total.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\greenE{27{,}000}+\purpleD{2{,}100} +\redD{60}+\blueD{3}=29{,}163$  So $9{,}721\times3=29{,}163$.

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 4 unequal parts, all with a width of 3 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled 27000, 2100, 60, and 3, and the lengths, also from left to right, are 9000, 700, 20, and 1.

hints.content: To find the area of each part, we multiply its length by its width.  $\begin{align}\greenE{A}&=\greenE{1{,}000\times5} \\\\ &=\greenE{5{,}000} \\\\ \purpleD{B}&=\purpleD{800\times5}\\\\ &=\purpleD{4{,}000} \\\\ \redD{C}&=\redD{60\times5}\\\\ &=\redD{300} \\\\ \blueD{D}&=\blueD{3\times5}\\\\ &=\blueD{15} \end{align}$

question.content: The following area model shows $4\times8{,}514$ broken into parts.    *The image is not drawn to scale.*    **Find the area of each rectangle.**  $A=$    $B=$    $C=$   $D=$    **Find the total area.**  $4\times8{,}514=$

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 4 unequal parts, all with a width of 4 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled A, B, C, and D, and the lengths, also from left to right, are 8000, 500, 10, and 4.

hints.content: The area of the whole rectangle is $4\times8{,}514$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: An area model using a rectangle of 4 unequal parts, all with a width of 4 but different lengths. From left to right, the parts are labeled A, B, C, and D. A curved bracket above all 4 parts is labeled 8514.

hints.content: To find the area of each part, we multiply its length by its width.  $\begin{align}\greenE{A}&=\greenE{8{,}000\times4} \\\\ &=\greenE{32{,}000} \\\\ \purpleD{B}&=\purpleD{500\times4}\\\\ &=\purpleD{2{,}000} \\\\ \redD{C}&=\redD{10\times4}\\\\ &=\redD{40} \\\\ \blueD{D}&=\blueD{4\times4}\\\\ &=\blueD{16} \end{align}$
